content.webTitle: Antonio Conte refuses to consider his Chelsea future until title is secured

fields.headline: Antonio Conte refuses to consider his Chelsea future until title is secured
fields.bodyText: Chelsea will attempt to claim the Premier League title at The Hawthorns on Friday with their manager, Antonio Conte, still heavily coveted by Internazionale and any talks over a contract extension apparently far from his priority. Victory against West Bromwich Albion would secure the Premier League at the first attempt under Conte’s stewardship, with an appeareance in the FA Cup final still to come. The manager has two years to run on his £6.5m-a-season deal but Chelsea are expected to offer him improved terms following the team’s startling success this term. Those negotiations will play out with Inter, under the money-flushed ownership of Suning Holdings group, having this week sacked their head coach, Stefano Pioli after only six months in charge. Their Chinese backers have prioritised Conte as a replacement and the Italian, asked to offer definitive assurances he would lead Chelsea into a Champions League campaign next season, was equivocal. “I have a contract for another two years with Chelsea but, for me and my players, the important thing is to be focused on the present,” Conte said. “This moment is very important. The future is not important for any single person: me or the players. It’s normal to have a lot of speculation around players and coaches, so it’s important not to lose the concentration and be focused as we try to reach this fantastic target. “It’s logical that, when you start in a new club, the will is to continue and improve your work for many years. For sure this is my will. But now the most important thing is to reach our target. To arrive at this moment, in this position, to have this great opportunity … we worked very hard for the whole season [for this]. Now it’s important to be ready and to try to do this step, to win and then to celebrate together.” Conte earns significantly less than Pep Guardiola, José Mourinho or Arsène Wenger, managers whose teams he has eclipsed comfortably this season. The scope is there to use Inter’s interest as a means of securing far better terms. Yet he suggested that, at such an elite level, the salary itself is less of a priority other than providing an indication of the worth a club places in his services. “The most important thing is to win, not the money,” he said. “But what the money does explain is your value; the real value of a player or a coach. If you show you deserve it, then you have earned [your] money. “If, in the future, we decide to extend my contract, then we’ll decide this. But it’s not important, this. I have two more years of contract and, I repeat, it’s important to win and write the history of this club with my players. Money is important but it’s not everything.” Conte has pointed to the confidence his players gained from an impressive second half comeback at Manchester City in early December as key to Chelsea’s anticipated title success as the leaders seek to secure the Premier League ahead of the weekend. A win at West Bromwich Albion on Friday would be enough to claim the trophy for the fifth time under Roman Abramovich’s ownership, and exorcise the memories of last season’s mid-table under-achievement. Chelsea had finished 10th under Mourinho and the interim management of Guus Hiddink, their lowest placing since the oligarch purchased the club in 2003, to suggest Conte had taken on a daunting task. Indeed, even after winning his first three games in charge, he was unconvinced they would boast enough to mount a challenge back in the autumn. Those concerns became more acute after successive league defeats to Liverpool and Arsenal in September. “We started this season with three wins but, honestly, I wasn’t tranquillo. I wasn’t calm,” he said. “I didn’t see what I was wanting to see. After three wins and a draw, you can lose one game like Liverpool, but a bad defeat against Arsenal ... after that defeat [3-0 at the Emirates], I understood we had to change something and find the right solution. We had to improve our tactical work. But, after that, I saw my team improving game by game, increasing their confidence in the work. In what we were doing.” He added: “If you ask me for one [definitive] moment when I knew we could compete for the title, I didn’t see one. But I saw my team improving, step by step and, for sure, when you play against City and win the way we did, confidence improved from then on.” Chelsea, having adopted the manager’s 3-4-3 formation after the Arsenal loss, had trailed 1-0 to Pep Guardiola’s much fancied side at the Etihad Stadium with their former player, Kevin de Bruyne, then missing a glorious chance to double the hosts’ lead. That proved pivotal with Diego Costa, Willian and Eden Hazard scoring in the last half-our to claim the points. Conte also acknowledged the part the emphatic 4-0 win over Mourinho’s Manchester United, back in late October, had played in convincing his players his methods would yield results. “Also the draw at Liverpool in January, when we missed a penalty 10 minutes from the end,” he said. “The confidence had improved a lot. These are moments when you understand you can fight for the title. But to win it in the first season? That’s difficult, and we are not there yet. We are building good foundations for this team at a transitional moment when we are losing players who wrote the history for this club. To build those foundations you need time.” Chelsea’s players trained at Stamford Bridge before travelling to the Midlands ahead of the game at the Hawthorns with three points required from their three remaining fixtures to confirm their status as champions. Conte has always stressed their success this term – they will play the FA Cup final against Arsenal later this month – is born of incessant work on the training ground. “It’s impossible to win this title without suffering,” he added. “When you work very hard, it’s normal to suffer. I’ve never seen a player who, during hard work, doesn’t suffer. I think that when you suffer you become stronger and then you are ready to face every situation, above all problematic situations during games. “This season, above all at the start, was not easy. We faced a lot of problems. When you arrive at a club who finished 10th in the league, it means that there was not only one problem, but lots of problems. So we tried to solve them – with my players, my staff and the club – and to find the right solution to change the situation created last season. My players and staff worked so hard to change this, so I have to thank them. But, above all, when I arrived here I found my players were great men, first of all, and also really good players. “It’s not easy to adapt to new methods or philosophies, and training very hard to change totally the work when you compare it to the work in the past. I think we’ve done a really good job. But I want this job to become great and fantastic because we have two really good opportunities, in the league and the FA Cup, to finish this season the right way.”
